subsection.p: Measuring angles in radians has other applications besides calculating arclength, and we will need to evaluate trigonometric functions of angles in radians. The sine, cosine, or tangent of a particular angle is the same whether the angle is measured in radians or in degrees.

Your calculator will give you the values \cos (3.5) \amp = -0.9364566873 \sin (3.5) \amp = -0.3507832277 Rounding to four places, we have \cos (3.5) = -0.9365 and \sin (3.5) = -0.3508. Note that 3.5 radians is a third-quadrant angle, so the signs of the trig values make sense.

note.p: Recall the formula for arclength when the angle is measured in radians: s = r \theta. If we solve for \theta, we see that \theta = \dfrac{s}{r}, a ratio of two lengths. The units of length cancel out, so that radian measure has no units; it is a "dimensionless" quantity.
We shall see that this property makes radians especially useful in applications. From now on we shall omit the tag "radians," and you may assume that any angle given without units is in radians.

subsection.p: Coterminal angles measured in radians have the same trig values, just as they do when measured in degrees. So adding or subtracting a multiple of 2 \pi to any angle results in a new angle in the same standard position.

Rounded to four places, your calculator will give you the values \cos (-4) \amp = -0.6536 \sin (-4) \amp = 0.7568 By adding 6.2832 (that's approximately 2\pi) to -4 we see that -4 radians is coterminal with 2.2832 radians, a second-quadrant angle. You can check that 2.2832 radians has (approximately) the same trig values as -4 radians.

subsection.title: The Special Values
subsection.p: Many applications of trigonometric functions, including most of the periodic functions we encountered in Chapter 4, use radians for input values, rather than degrees. For this reason, it is important to know the trig values for the special angles, which you learned in degrees in Chapter 2, when the angles are given in radians.
You should learn these function values, so that ou can find trig values for the special angles in all four quadrants.

Recall that we use reference angles to define the trigonometric ratios for angles greater than 90\degree. (See Section 4.1 to review reference angles.) The figure below shows how to calculate reference angles in radians. Note that the formulas are the same as those for degrees if we replace 180\degree by \pi!

sidebyside.p: The reference angle for \dfrac{2\pi}{3} is \pi - \dfrac{2\pi}{3} = \dfrac{\pi}{3}, and the tangent is negative in the second quadrant. (See the figure at right.) Thus, \tan \dfrac{2\pi}{3} = -\tan \dfrac{\pi}{3} = -\sqrt{3}

The reference angle for \dfrac{5\pi}{4} is \dfrac{5\pi}{4} - \pi = \dfrac{\pi}{4}, and the cosine is negative in the third quadrant, so \cos \dfrac{5\pi}{4} = - \cos \dfrac{\pi}{4} = \dfrac{-1}{\sqrt{2}}

note.p: At this point, you may feel that expressions such as ~\cos \dfrac{5\pi}{4} = \dfrac{-1}{\sqrt{2}}~ look like hieroglyphics. Keep in mind that \dfrac{5\pi}{4} and \dfrac{-1}{\sqrt{2}} are just numbers, so the equation above says that "the cosine of an angle of 3.9 radians is about -0.7."

subsection.title: Sine and Cosine of Real Numbers
subsection.p: In Section 6.1 we derived the arclength formula, s = r\theta, where \theta is measured in radians, and observed that, on a unit circle, where r = 1, the measure of a positive angle in radians is equal to the length of the arc it spans. This is an important observation, because it allows us to define the sine and cosine as functions of real numbers, instead of as functions of angles.

sidebyside.p: Consider the unit circle shown at right, and the angle \theta determined by the arc of length t. The radian measure of \theta is the same as the length t of the arc. (For example, in this figure \theta = t = 2.)

assemblage.title: Sine and Cosine of Real Numbers

subsection.p: We can think of the definition this way: to find the sine or cosine of a real number t, we draw an arc of length t on a unit circle, and then find the sine or cosine of the angle \theta determined by the arc.

note.p: In practice, there is no difference between finding the sine or cosine of the number 2 and the sine or cosine of an angle of 2 radians: in each case we set the calculator in Radian mode and evaluate

subsection.p: So, in some sense then, a trig function of a radian is the same as a trig function of a real number. This result is so important that it bears repeating: to find the sine or cosine of a real number t, we find the sine or cosine of the angle t radians. We can now use the trigonometric functions to model periodic behavior as functions of time, or indeed, of any variable.

statement.p: The sunset time in Stockholm, Sweden, on the nth day of the year can be modeled by T = 3.11 \sin (0.017n - 1.38) + 6.03 where T is given in hours after noon. Find the sunset time on January 1 (day n = 1) and on July 1 (day n = 182).

solution.p: Evaluate the function for n = \alert{1} to find T = 3.11 \sin (0.017(\alert{1}) - 1.38) + 6.03 = 2.99 On January 1, sunset in Stockholm occurs about 2.99 hours after noon, or at 2:59 pm.

Evaluate the function at n = \alert{182} to find T = 3.11 \sin (0.017(\alert{182}) - 1.38) + 6.03 = 9.11 On July 1, sunset occurs about 9.11 hours after noon, or at 9:07 pm. (Actually, 10:07 pm, because of daylight savings time.)

subsection.title: Coordinates on a Unit Circle
subsection.p: There is another useful connection between the unit circle and the trigonometric functions. Consider an arc of length t in standard position on a unit circle, and the angle \theta spanned by the arc. Because r = 1 on a unit circle, \cos \theta = \dfrac{x}{r} = \dfrac{x}{1}~~~~\text{and}~~~~ \sin \theta = \dfrac{y}{r} = \dfrac{y}{1} But because \cos t = \cos \theta and \sin t = \sin \theta, we have \cos t = x ~~~~ \text{and} ~~~~ \sin t = y We have established the following result for the sine and cosine of a real number t.

sidebyside.p: The coordinates of the point P determined by an arc of length t in standard position on a unit circle are \blert{(x, y) = (\cos t, \sin t)}

subsection.p: We sometimes call the trigonometric functions of real numbers, \sin t and \cos t, the circular functionscircular functioncircular functionsinecircular functioncosine, because they are defined by the coordinates of points on a unit circle.

subsection.title: The Tangent Function
subsection.p: We can also define the tangent function for real numbers. Let P(x,y) be the terminal point of an arc of length t in standard position on a unit circle. Then

sidebyside.p: \blert{\tan t = \dfrac{y}{x}} Of course, this definition agrees with our earlier definition of the tangent function for angles, because the point P lies on the terminal side of the angle \theta = t radians.
